Award.AwardTitle: Learning Evolution through Model-Based Inquiry: Supporting Agent-Based Modeling in STEM Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the investigators design and explore the use of agent based models in advancing high school students' understanding of evolutionary biology while promoting their computational thinking skills. Using the NetLogo programming environment, the students and teachers focus on the relationship of evolutionary change at the level of the organism (micro-evolution) with evolution at the population level (macro-evolution). This is one of the basic concepts in evolution that seems most difficult for students to grasp. The use of NetLogo is well-suited toward this end given that it can depict how changes at the individual level relate to shifts in the population of the organism as a whole.

The research examines the impact of using such methods on student outcomes including learning and student interest. The learning environment is designed to examine students working either alone or in pairs at laptop computers or as a group on a table top computer. Design research is used to explore the relative effects of these approaches. Inner city students in grades 9 through 11 are the study population.

This research is important because if learning technologies and modeling evolution as a computational problem can help overcome a critical sticking point in students' understanding in this area, which is core to the biology curriculum, then student learning of evolution can be improved. If the approach used by the investigators is effective, then it demonstrates that significant changes in the productivity of student learning can be achieved by the use of learning technology. In addition, the project expects to contribute to the theory and practice of learning using instructional technologies, agent based models, and computational models. Because inner city students are involved in the study, the findings should be particularly beneficial to this group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is widespread and growing agreement that computing should play a more prominent role throughout our education system. The next generation of learners will require a high level of fluency with modes of thinking and inquiry in which computers act as partners. While many students experience computing (via the Web and apps), few students understand computation, and even fewer have experience using computers as tools for scientific inquiry. These skills and perspectives are essential for full and effective participation in society.

This project explored the use of computational modeling activities in science classrooms and museums as new ways for students to learn core concepts of evolutionary biology. Through project funding, we developed a series of computational models of evolution that are appropriate for middle-school-aged learners. The models are based on the NetLogo agent-based modeling software (https://ccl.northwestern.edu/netlogo/) For some of these models, we provided a simple computer programming interface that we developed called NetTango (http://tidal.sesp.northwestern.edu/nettango/) that enables children to program the behavior of simulated organisms in the models by dragging and dropping visual blocks.

For example, students can assemble chains of visual programming blocks with names like move, left, right, and hatch to form programs that can result in changes to a simulated population of organisms over successive generations. Importantly, children never program these outcomes directly—they never write code that explicitly says, "make the organisms get bigger". Instead, outcomes emerge as the aggregate result of hundreds of individuals enacting rules from the same program. These outcomes can be surprising and counterintuitive, but because they result from programs that learners create themselves, our hypothesis has been that they would encourage explanations that attribute change to emergence resulting from individual interactions. Our studies have borne out this hypothesis.

We tested these technology designs in a large natural history museum and with hundreds of middle school students. Results from a study in six middle school science classrooms during a three-week instructional unit showed significant improvements in students’ understanding and attitudes around evolution and natural selection. Our qualitative and quantitative analysis of computer log data, pre- and post-interviews, written pre- and post-tests, and video recordings is helping us understand how computational thinking can be used to support student learning in science classrooms.

We have disseminated our work in journals such as   Science Education, Communications of the ACM, the Journal of Science Education and Technology, and the Journal of Research in Science Teaching as well as conferences such as Interaction Design and Children and the International Conference of the Learning Sciences.
